CCC_13.title: Child Care Centers
CCC_13.description: The number of licensed child care locations per square mile.
CCC_13.importance:
Foundational stages of brain development that guide behavior and health for years to come occur before age 5. Research has shown that positive, healthful early development environments lead to more resilient brain development and greater flexibility in the acquisition of skills throughout life. Stable, high-quality child care in the early years of child development has life-long implications.

Access to quality care can be compromised by inadequate local facilities or public transit service, challenges posed by neighborhood safety and other environmental or economic factors.
CCC_13.tech_notes: This measure includes both child care centers and family child care homes which are licensed by the state of North Carolina’s Division of Child Care and Early Development. It does not include unlicensed locations. Data was collected from April 2013 and reflects a snapshot of the calendar year’s licensed centers.
CCC_13.source: Division of Child Care and Early Development, 2013.
CCC_13.links:
About Licensing for Child Care Centers
Child Care Services Association
Durham's Partnership for Children
More About Star Ratings
Smart Start NC
Local Resources for Families with Young Children

CC45_13.title: Child Care Centers with 4 or 5 Star Ratings
CC45_13.description: The percentage of licensed child care centers that have ratings of 4 or 5 stars.
CC45_13.importance: Star ratings issued by the NC Division of Child Development and Early Education are based primarily on a licensed program’s staff education and program standards. They reflect the strengths of child care programs in these two areas, above and beyond basic compliance with state child care regulations.  For more information about licensing and the star rating system see the links in Additional Resources.
CC45_13.tech_notes: This measure includes both child care centers and family child care homes which are licensed by the state of North Carolina’s Division of Child Care and Early Development. It does not include unlicensed locations. Data was collected from April 2013 and reflects a snapshot of the calendar year’s licensed centers.
CC45_13.source: Division of Child Care and Early Development, 2013.
CC45_13.links:
About Licensing for Child Care Centers
Child Care Services Association
Durham's Partnership for Children
More About Star Ratings
Smart Start NC
Local Resources for Families with Young Children

PTPRIM_13.title: Primary election participation
PTPRIM_13.description: The percent of active voters participating in 2012 primary elections.
PTPRIM_13.importance:
Not all registered voters vote in a primary election, though in North Carolina they can. In some states, only those affiliated with a party are able to vote for their party's candidates. In North Carolina any registered voter can cast a ballot in a primary.

Typically, many fewer individuals vote in primary elections, and those that do are expressing additional interest in local or partisan issues and policies. As an indicator of engagement this measurement is both a reflection of above-average voting activity, and a reflection of deeper engagement in the political process and its institutions.
PTPRIM_13.tech_notes: The data included in this measure reflect active voters only. The Board of Elections codes voters 'inactive' when their most recent address may be inaccurate. Due to the potentially inaccurate addresses of inactive voters, this spatial analysis relies only on the active voters. As of January 2014, there were 176,148 active voters out of a total 200,885 registered in Durham County.
PTPRIM_13.links:
Durham County Board of Elections
NC Voter ID Requirements

PTPRIM_14.title: Primary election participation
PTPRIM_14.description: The percent of active voters participating in 2012 primary elections.
PTPRIM_14.importance:
Not all registered voters vote in a primary election, though in North Carolina they can. In some states, only those affiliated with a party are able to vote for their party's candidates. In North Carolina any registered voter can cast a ballot in a primary.

Typically, many fewer individuals vote in primary elections, and those that do are expressing additional interest in local or partisan issues and policies. As an indicator of engagement this measurement is both a reflection of above-average voting activity, and a reflection of deeper engagement in the political process and its institutions.
PTPRIM_14.tech_notes: The data included in this measure reflect active voters only. The Board of Elections codes voters 'inactive' when their most recent address may be inaccurate. Due to the potentially inaccurate addresses of inactive voters, this spatial analysis relies only on the active voters. As of January 2014, there were 176,148 active voters out of a total 200,885 registered in Durham County.
PTPRIM_14.links:
Durham County Board of Elections
NC Voter ID Requirements

PTGNRL_13.title: General election participation
PTGNRL_13.description: The percent of active voters participating in 2012 general election.
PTGNRL_13.importance: Participation of registered voters in general elections reflects one of the primary activities of civic engagement. There are many reasons voters may or may not participate in a general election (which occurs every four years and includes the election of a presidential candidate). At its root, where a voting age population exists this measurement reflects the degree of community engagement in our electoral process and the perception that it is meaningful in the lives of community members.
PTGNRL_13.tech_notes: The data included in this measure reflect active voters only. The Board of Elections codes voters 'inactive' when their most recent address may be inaccurate. Due to the potentially inaccurate addresses of inactive voters, this spatial analysis relies only on the active voters. As of January 2014, there were 176,148 active voters out of a total 200,885 registered in Durham County.
PTGNRL_13.links:
Durham County Board of Elections
NC Voter ID Requirements

PTGNRL_14.importance: Participation of registered voters in general elections reflects one of the primary activities of civic engagement. BUS_13.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Bus Stops
BUS_13.description: The percent of households that are within one quarter-mile of DATA and Triangle Transit bus stops.
BUS_13.importance: Household proximity to public transit indicates transportation options for those with cars and indicates access to regional transportation for those without cars. This measurement is one of three included in the Compass that gauge the effectiveness of public transit service to neighborhoods (daily and nightly bus arrivals are the other two).
BUS_13.tech_notes: Households include all residential units, not just residential parcels. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies. Bus stop locations used in this calculation are those active from January 1 to July 1 of 2013.
BUS_13.links:
Triangle Transit
Durham Area Transit Authority

BUS_14.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Bus Stops
BUS_14.description: The percent of households that are within one quarter-mile of DATA and Triangle Transit bus stops.
BUS_14.importance: Household proximity to public transit indicates transportation options for those with cars and indicates access to regional transportation for those without cars. This measurement is one of three included in the Compass that gauge the effectiveness of public transit service to neighborhoods (daily and nightly bus arrivals are the other two).
BUS_14.tech_notes: Households include all residential units, not just residential parcels. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies. Bus stop locations used in this calculation are those active in the spring of 2014.
BUS_14.links:
Triangle Transit
Durham Area Transit Authority

DAYTRIP_13.title: Total Daily Bus Arrivals
DAYTRIP_13.description: The count of daytime bus arrivals for all routes in the selected blockgroup.
DAYTRIP_13.importance: This measurement is one of three included in the Compass that gauge the effectiveness of public transit service to neighborhoods (nightly bus arrivals and households within a quarter mile of transit stops are the other two).
DAYTRIP_13.tech_notes: Bus routes used in this calculation are those active as of August 28, 2013 and do not serve all areas of Durham County. Click here for a map of the Triangle Transit service area and here for a map of DATA's service area.
DAYTRIP_13.links:
Triangle Transit
Durham Area Transit Authority

DAYTRIP_14.title: Total Daily Bus Arrivals
DAYTRIP_14.description: The count of daytime bus arrivals for all routes in the selected blockgroup.
DAYTRIP_14.importance: This measurement is one of three included in the Compass that gauge the effectiveness of public transit service to neighborhoods (nightly bus arrivals and households within a quarter mile of transit stops are the other two).
DAYTRIP_14.tech_notes: Bus routes used in this calculation are those active in the spring of 2014 and do not serve all areas of Durham County. Click here for a map of the Triangle Transit service area and here for a map of DATA's service area.

EVETRIP_13.importance: This measurement is one of three that gauge the effectiveness of public transit service to neighborhoods (daily bus arrivals and households within a quarter mile of transit stops are the other two).

BANK_13.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Banks
BANK_13.description: The percent of area households within a quarter-mile of a commercial bank or credit union.
BANK_13.importance: Banking is a core community service, providing financial planning, savings, and management services to households. Neighborhoods without easy access to such core services are transportation dependent for primary needs, leading to higher costs of living and reliance on inadequate convenience services.
BANK_13.tech_notes: This measurement includes both commercial bank locations and credit unions. These are identified primarily by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) codes 52211 and 52213. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies.
BANK_13.source: City of Durham Transportation, Tax Administration/City-County GIS (2013)

BANK_14.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Banks
BANK_14.description: The percent of area households within a quarter-mile of a commercial bank or credit union.
BANK_14.importance: Banking is a core community service, providing financial planning, savings, and management services to households. Neighborhoods without easy access to such core services are transportation dependent for primary needs, leading to higher costs of living and reliance on inadequate convenience services.
BANK_14.tech_notes: This measurement includes both commercial bank locations and credit unions. These are identified primarily by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) codes 52211 and 52213. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies.
BANK_14.source: City of Durham Transportation, Tax Administration/City-County GIS (2014)

GRCR_13.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Full Service Grocers
GRCR_13.description: The percent of area households within a quarter-mile of full-service grocery stores.
GRCR_13.importance: Grocery stores are among the core services a community needs, providing reliable access to basic foods: dry goods, meat, fresh produce, and dairy. Neighborhoods without easy access to grocers are transportation-dependent for core needs, leading to higher costs of living and reliance on inadequate convenience food sources.
GRCR_13.tech_notes: Grocery stores include chain groceries and independent full-service stores. These are identified primarily by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code 44511. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies.
GRCR_13.source: City of Durham Transportation, Tax Administration/City-County GIS (2013)
GRCR_13.links:
Urban Ministries of Durham
Food Bank of Central & Eastern North Carolina
Durham County Food Pantries

GRCR_14.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Full Service Grocers
GRCR_14.description: The percent of area households within a quarter-mile of full-service grocery stores.
GRCR_14.importance: Grocery stores are among the core services a community needs, providing reliable access to basic foods: dry goods, meat, fresh produce, and dairy. Neighborhoods without easy access to grocers are transportation-dependent for core needs, leading to higher costs of living and reliance on inadequate convenience food sources.
GRCR_14.tech_notes: Grocery stores include chain groceries and independent full-service stores. These are identified primarily by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code 44511. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies.
GRCR_14.source: City of Durham Transportation, Tax Administration/City-County GIS (2014)
GRCR_14.links:

Food Bank of Central & Eastern North Carolina
Durham County Food Pantries

PHAR_13.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Pharmacies
PHAR_13.description: The percent of area households within a quarter-mile of pharmacies.
PHAR_13.importance: Pharmacies are among the core services a community needs. They allow access to prescriptions and basic household pharmaceuticals, medical devices and preventative care products. In addition, many pharmacies offer 'minute-clinics' for basic primary care services.
PHAR_13.tech_notes: Pharmacies include traditional storefront locations of independent and chain drug stores, as well as big-box retail locations. These are identified primarily by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code 44611. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies.
PHAR_13.source: City of Durham Transportation, Tax Administration/City-County GIS (2013)
PHAR_13.links:
Senior PharmAssist
Durham County Public Health Department

PHAR_14.title: Households Within Walking Distance to Pharmacies
PHAR_14.description: The percent of area households within a quarter-mile of pharmacies.
PHAR_14.importance: Pharmacies are among the core services a community needs. They allow access to prescriptions and basic household pharmaceuticals, medical devices and preventative care products. In addition, many pharmacies offer 'minute-clinics' for basic primary care services.
PHAR_14.tech_notes: Pharmacies include traditional storefront locations of independent and chain drug stores, as well as big-box retail locations. These are identified primarily by North American Industry Classification System (NAICS) code 44611. The 1/4 mile distance is Euclidean, or as-the-crow-flies.
PHAR_14.source: City of Durham Transportation, Tax Administration/City-County GIS (2014)
PHAR_14.links:
Senior PharmAssist
Durham County Public Health Department

SWTORD_13.title: Sidewalk-to-Roadway Ratio
SWTORD_13.description: The ratio of sidewalk length to road length in the selected area.
SWTORD_13.importance: This ratio indicates how well-served an area is by sidewalks. The ratio is to be read as the number of sidewalk feet for every hundred feet of roadway in a neighborhood. If the number is more than 100, it is likely due to sidewalks existing on both sides of many neighborhood streets.
SWTORD_13.tech_notes: The intention of this measurement is to indicate how well neighborhood roads serve pedestrians. Pedestrian or bike paths not adjacent to roadways are not among the sidewalks counted here. Areas reporting 'N/A' are outside City limits and do not contain annexed communities - the City does not maintain or build sidewalks in those areas.
SWTORD_13.links:
2013 Sidewalk Repairs and Curb Ramps (SW-29)
City-Maintained Streets

SWTORD_14.title: Sidewalk-to-Roadway Ratio
SWTORD_14.description: The ratio of sidewalk length to road length in the selected area.
SWTORD_14.importance: This ratio indicates how well-served an area is by sidewalks. The ratio is to be read as the number of sidewalk feet for every hundred feet of roadway in a neighborhood. If the number is more than 100, it is likely due to sidewalks existing on both sides of many neighborhood streets.
SWTORD_14.tech_notes: The intention of this measurement is to indicate how well neighborhood roads serve pedestrians. Pedestrian or bike paths not adjacent to roadways are not among the sidewalks counted here. Areas reporting 'N/A' are outside City limits and do not contain annexed communities - the City does not maintain or build sidewalks in those areas.
SWTORD_14.links:
Construction and Design Projects - Active
City-Maintained Streets

LUDIV_13.title: Land Use Diversity
LUDIV_13.description: The indexed value of diversity of land uses in these categories: agriculture, residential, commercial, recreation, industrial, community services, public services (utilities), wild and forested lands.
LUDIV_13.importance: The diversity of land uses can reflect the richness of social and economic life in a community. Just as mixed uses in a single property are desirable for bringing people and their service or amenity needs closer to one another, the same is true within neighborhoods. Land use diversity can have transportation, health and environmental associations as well as create greater collocation of jobs and housing.
LUDIV_13.tech_notes: A higher value in this measure reflects both a higher number of land use categories present and more properties in each category. A measure of 100 would mean each of the possible types of land use is present and that there is an equal number of each. A measure of 0 would mean only one type is present. The calculation of this measurement uses the Simpson Index of Diversity.
LUDIV_13.source: City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services and Durham County Tax Administration (2013)
LUDIV_13.links:
The Measurement of the Level of Mixed Land Uses: A Synthetic Approach
Durham City-County Planning Department

LUDIV_14.title: Land Use Diversity
LUDIV_14.description: The indexed value of diversity of land uses in these categories: agriculture, residential, commercial, recreation, industrial, community services, public services (utilities), wild and forested lands.
LUDIV_14.importance: The diversity of land uses can reflect the richness of social and economic life in a community. Just as mixed uses in a single property are desirable for bringing people and their service or amenity needs closer to one another, the same is true within neighborhoods. Land use diversity can have transportation, health and environmental associations as well as create greater collocation of jobs and housing.
LUDIV_14.tech_notes: A higher value in this measure reflects both a higher number of land use categories present and more properties in each category. A measure of 100 would mean each of the possible types of land use is present and that there is an equal number of each. A measure of 0 would mean only one type is present. The calculation of this measurement uses the Simpson Index of Diversity.
LUDIV_14.source: City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services and Durham County Tax Administration (2014)
LUDIV_14.links:
The Measurement of the Level of Mixed Land Uses: A Synthetic Approach
Durham City-County Planning Department

RVALPSM_13.title: Residential Building Permit Values
RVALPSM_13.description: The value per square mile of residential building permits filed during the 2012 calendar year.
RVALPSM_13.importance: Residential building permit values reflect active investment in property, whether improvements or maintenance for existing residences or development of new homes.
RVALPSM_13.tech_notes: The value of residential building permits for each boundary divided by the area (in square miles) of each. These permits include new construction as well as renovations and exclude demolitions.
RVALPSM_13.links:
Durham Office of Economic and Workforce Development
Durham City/County Inspections
Durham Development Tracker
Durham Community Development Department

RVALPSM_14.description: The value per square mile of residential building permits filed during the 2012 calendar year.
RVALPSM_14.importance: Residential building permit values reflect active investment in property, whether improvements or maintenance for existing residences or development of new homes.
RVALPSM_14.tech_notes: The value of residential building permits for each boundary divided by the area (in square miles) of each. These permits include new construction as well as renovations and exclude demolitions.
RVALPSM_14.links:

CVALPSM_13.title: Commercial Building Permit Values
CVALPSM_13.description: The value per square mile of commercial building permits filed during the 2012 calendar year.
CVALPSM_13.importance: Commercial building permit values reflect active investment in property, whether improvements to or maintenance of existing properties or development of new commercial properties.
CVALPSM_13.tech_notes: The value of commercial, business, and industrial building permits for each boundary divided by the area (in square miles) of each. These permits include new construction as well as renovations and exclude demolitions.
CVALPSM_13.links:
Durham Office of Economic and Workforce Development
Durham City/County Inspections

CVALPSM_14.title: Commercial Building Permit Values
CVALPSM_14.description: The value per square mile of commercial building permits filed during the 2012 calendar year.
CVALPSM_14.importance: Commercial building permit values reflect active investment in property, whether improvements to or maintenance of existing properties or development of new commercial properties.
CVALPSM_14.tech_notes: The value of commercial, business, and industrial building permits for each boundary divided by the area (in square miles) of each. These permits include new construction as well as renovations and exclude demolitions.
CVALPSM_14.links:
Durham Office of Economic and Workforce Development
Durham City/County Inspections
Durham Development Tracker

COR_13.title: Residential Certificates of Occupancy
COR_13.description: The number of certificates of occupancy issued for residential property, per square mile.
COR_13.importance: Certificates of occupancy are issued for completed renovations or new construction. Newly completed residential COs indicate recent investment in real estate and lead to increased property values. Overall, this reflects improvement to a neighborhood's housing stock.
COR_13.tech_notes: COs included here are the following types: residential, single family, townhouse, condominium, duplex, manufactured homes, and mixed-use residential. The count of these per neighborhood or blockgroup is divided by the area in square miles within the City/County Inspections districts.
COR_13.links:
Durham Office of Economic and Workforce Development
Durham City/County Inspections
Durham Development Tracker

COR_14.title: Residential Certificates of Occupancy
COR_14.description: The number of certificates of occupancy issued for residential property, per square mile.
COR_14.importance: Certificates of occupancy are issued for completed renovations or new construction. Newly completed residential COs indicate recent investment in real estate and lead to increased property values. Overall, this reflects improvement to a neighborhood's housing stock.
COR_14.tech_notes: COs included here are the following types: residential, single family, townhouse, condominium, duplex, manufactured homes, and mixed-use residential. The count of these per neighborhood or blockgroup is divided by the area in square miles within the City/County Inspections districts.
COR_14.links:
Durham Office of Economic and Workforce Development
Durham City/County Inspections
Durham Development Tracker

COB_13.title: Commercial Certificates of Occupancy
COB_13.description: The number of certificates of occupancy issued for commercial and industrial property, per square mile.
COB_13.importance: Certificates of occupancy are issued for completed renovations or new construction. Newly completed commercial COs indicate recent investment in real estate (an economic benefit to a neighborhood) and additional new commercial space, which is both an opportunity for local business growth and potential for improved access to core needs and employment.
COB_13.tech_notes: COs included here are the following types: business, mercantile, factory industrial, and mixed use commercial. The count of these per neighborhood or blockgroup is divided by the area in square miles within the City/County Inspections districts.
COB_13.links:
Durham Office of Economic and Workforce Development
Durham City/County Inspections
Durham Development Tracker

COB_14.title: Commercial Certificates of Occupancy
COB_14.description: The number of certificates of occupancy issued for commercial and industrial property, per square mile.
COB_14.importance: Certificates of occupancy are issued for completed renovations or new construction. Newly completed commercial COs indicate recent investment in real estate (an economic benefit to a neighborhood) and additional new commercial space, which is both an opportunity for local business growth and potential for improved access to core needs and employment.
COB_14.tech_notes: COs included here are the following types: business, mercantile, factory industrial, and mixed use commercial. The count of these per neighborhood or blockgroup is divided by the area in square miles within the City/County Inspections districts.
COB_14.links:
Durham Office of Economic and Workforce Development
Durham City/County Inspections
Durham Development Tracker

RAVGYR_13.title: Average Year of Residential Construction
RAVGYR_13.description: The average year built of all types of residential construction.
RAVGYR_13.importance: The age of housing generally reflects the development history of the city - Durham's oldest neighborhoods have average residential construction years in the 1920s and 30s. This measure can also indicate greater maintenance needs for a community's housing stock. If a community has a concentration of building code violations and aging housing it may warrant focused efforts in repairing, restoring, and preserving housing.
RAVGYR_13.tech_notes: The average age of all residential units - including single-family, multi-family, townhouse and all other residential categories.
RAVGYR_13.links:
City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services
City of Durham Community Development
Preservation Durham
Open Durham

RAVGYR_14.title: Average Year of Residential Construction
RAVGYR_14.description: The average year built of all types of residential construction.
RAVGYR_14.importance: The age of housing generally reflects the development history of the city - Durham's oldest neighborhoods have average residential construction years in the 1920s and 30s. This measure can also indicate greater maintenance needs for a community's housing stock. If a community has a concentration of building code violations and aging housing it may warrant focused efforts in repairing, restoring, and preserving housing.
RAVGYR_14.tech_notes: The average age of all residential units - including single-family, multi-family, townhouse and all other residential categories.
RAVGYR_14.links:
City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services
City of Durham Community Development
Preservation Durham
Open Durham

PRUNSD_13.title: Poor and Unsound State of Repair
PRUNSD_13.description: The percentage of residences determined to be in poor or unsound condition.
PRUNSD_13.importance: A property's state of repair is often directly influential on the quality of life of its occupants. This measure reports the two most severe categories of deterioration, poor and unsound, as a percentage of all owner- and renter-occupied residential units. For neighborhood areas showing the highest concentrations of poor and unsound properties (between 3.5% and 8% of all residences) the impacts can be considerable to neighborhood safety, public health, and even property values. In those areas, multiple poor and unsound properties can be found on a single block.
PRUNSD_13.tech_notes: State of repair for all properties is reported in 5 categories in the Tax Administration's property records. The five categories are good, normal, fair, poor, and unsound. The latter two are defined as follows: poor, showing marked deterioriation; unsound, may be unfit for habitation or condemned. For the measure reported here, these two categories are combined.
PRUNSD_13.links:
City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services
City of Durham Community Development

PRUNSD_14.title: Poor and Unsound State of Repair
PRUNSD_14.description: The percentage of residences determined to be in poor or unsound condition.
PRUNSD_14.importance: A property's state of repair is often directly influential on the quality of life of its occupants. This measure reports the two most severe categories of deterioration, poor and unsound, as a percentage of all owner- and renter-occupied residential units. For neighborhood areas showing the highest concentrations of poor and unsound properties (between 3.5% and 8% of all residences) the impacts can be considerable to neighborhood safety, public health, and even property values. In those areas, multiple poor and unsound properties can be found on a single block.
PRUNSD_14.tech_notes: State of repair for all properties is reported in 5 categories in the Tax Administration's property records. The five categories are good, normal, fair, poor, and unsound. The latter two are defined as follows: poor, showing marked deterioriation; unsound, may be unfit for habitation or condemned. For the measure reported here, these two categories are combined.
PRUNSD_14.links:
City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services
City of Durham Community Development

RCODEV_13.title: Minimum Housing Code Violations
RCODEV_13.description: Minimum housing code violations per 100 dwelling units.
RCODEV_13.importance: Violations of the City minimum housing code can interfere with the safety and quality of life of residents and can have a negative impact on surrounding homes and properties. The City of Durham minimum housing standards code is enforced by the Neighborhood Improvement Services department.
RCODEV_13.tech_notes: The number of minimum housing code violations divided by the estimated dwelling unit count, multiplied by 100. This measurement includes all minimum housing code violations, excluding calls found to be not in violation. This does include orders to repair, demolish, unsafe structures, and boarded properties. NOTE: These numbers may be higher in areas where the City's Proactive Rental Inspection Program (PRIP) is active. For a map of these areas, please refer to the PRIP link in Additional Resources. Because minimum housing code is enforced by the City of Durham but not outside the city in Durham County, this measurement reflects a City-only service and parts of Durham County are not represented by this data. Dwelling unit estimates for this measure therefore only count those within the City administrative boundary.
RCODEV_13.source: City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services (2012)
RCODEV_13.links:
Proactive Rental Inspection Program
Durham One Call
North Carolina Minimum Housing Code
Neighborhood Improvement Services

Because minimum housing code is enforced by the City of Durham but not outside the city in Durham County, this measurement reflects a City-only service and parts of Durham County are not represented by this data. WCODEV_13.title: Unmaintained Property Violations
WCODEV_13.description: Unmaintained property violations per 100 dwelling units.
WCODEV_13.importance: Unmaintained properties can have a serious impact on neighborhoods. Unmaintained lots can influence property values for surrounding homes, they can draw increased criminal activity, and they can become home to unwanted vermin and pests. The City of Durham ordinance regarding unmaintained properties is enforced by the Neighborhood Improvement Services department.
WCODEV_13.tech_notes: The number of unmaintained property violations divided by the estimated dwelling unit count, multiplied by 100. This measurement includes all unmaintained property ('weedy lot') violations, not including calls found to be not in violation or those involving commercial properties. This measurement, along with residential building code violations and abandoned, hazardous or junked vehicles reflect a City-only service and parts of Durham County are not represented by this data.
WCODEV_13.source: City of Durham Neighborhood Improvement Services (2012)
WCODEV_13.links:
Durham One Call
Solid Waste Collection Services
City of Durham Weeds, Trash, and Debris Ordinances
Neighborhood Improvement Services

V_SQM_13.title: Crimes with a Violent Component
V_SQM_13.description: The number of crimes per square mile with a violent component that occurred in calendar year 2012.
V_SQM_13.importance: The violent crime rate is an indicator of basic community safety and well-being. Residents, organizations, and government alike can use this information to address high rates of violent crime where they exist and to monitor the impact of efforts to stop violent crime.
V_SQM_13.tech_notes: Violent crimes are commonly reported with parts 1 and 2 separate. This measurement is different, including all part 1 violent crimes and these part 2 crimes: simple assaults, certain sex offenses, child abuse and kidnapping. The number of these violent crimes occurring in each boundary is divided by the area (in square miles) of the boundary, rather than the population. This is intended to control for how crime often happens in areas that are less populated. For more detailed Durham crime reporting visit RAIDS Online.
V_SQM_13.source: Durham Police Department and Durham County Sheriff's Office (2012)
V_SQM_13.links:
RAIDS Online
Durham Police Department
Durham County Office of the Sheriff
Citizens Police Academy
Partners Against Crime

P_SQM_13.title: Crimes Involving Property
P_SQM_13.description: The number of crimes per square mile involving property that occurred in calendar year 2012.
P_SQM_13.importance: The property crime rate is directly related to resident safety and well-being. Property crime also impacts perception of neighborhood safety and often represents a loss of or damage to private property.
P_SQM_13.tech_notes: Property crimes are commonly reported with parts 1 and 2 separate. This measurement is different, including all part 1 property crimes and these part 2 crimes: fraud, forgery, embezzlement, counterfeiting, stolen property and vandalism. The number of property crimes occurring in each boundary is divided by the area (in square miles) of the boundary, rather than the population. This is intended to control for how crime often happens in areas that are less populated. For more detailed Durham crime reporting visit RAIDS Online.
P_SQM_13.source: Durham Police Department and Durham County Sheriff's Office (2012)
P_SQM_13.links:
RAIDS Online
Durham Police Department
Durham County Office of the Sheriff
Citizens Police Academy
Partners Against Crime

D_SQM_13.title: Drug-Related Crimes
D_SQM_13.description: The number of drug-related crimes per square mile that occurred in calendar year 2012.
D_SQM_13.importance: Drug crimes impact individuals, households, neighborhoods and the community as a whole. Drug crimes are often linked with other violent and property crimes, as well as with physical and mental health issues.
D_SQM_13.tech_notes: Drug-related crimes include all incidents involving drug and paraphernalia manufacturing, distributing, and possession charges. For more detailed Durham crime reporting visit RAIDS Online.
D_SQM_13.source: Durham Police Department and Durham County Sheriff's Office (2012)
D_SQM_13.links:
RAIDS Online
Durham Police Department
Durham County Office of the Sheriff
Citizens Police Academy
Partners Against Crime
